Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. We had gone away together the summer before, to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't a success because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and myself. They call me Milly, though my name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school, Dekko Deacon sounding nice, I guess. He and Strafe were at school together, which is why we call Strafe by his surname like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds were before they moved from England to Ireland. Quite a coincidence, we always think. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling her welcome again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive, as she's rarely not waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' She referred to the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of putting numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles redecoration and repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, entering the hall from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt the others thinking that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn, all was well. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led the way to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not for long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man on his own and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full: from where we sat in the window, we could see some of them walking on the lawns, others taking the cliff path to the seashore. In the morning we'd do the same: we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed. Since we first came here, we'd all fallen in love with every part of its beautiful landscape.'

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, called chalets, that are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl isn't a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not live in the chalet. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk about a mile to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last guest has finished breakfast, by about 9.30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go skiing herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4.30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast with a terrible headache.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4.30 p.m.' Sometimes they are confused and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says. '

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was about six years older, visited his factory one day. She wore overalls and big, unattractive shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by a bush of curly hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour asking to see his factory, and sometimes he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or, if they seemed very serious, by giving a short tour. Rita Cohen seemed almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how Marie's father made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand,' Seymour replied. She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' He was pleased that she was interested in every detail. 'They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' 'Not yet,' she said. 'Well, you should visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you if you want. They're old-fashioned places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. It's said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old tanning relics were found in Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it was interesting once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. Start him on gloves, and he'll talk for two days. That's typical: glove makers love the trade and everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' 'I can't say I have,' she replied. 'Never seen anything made?' 'I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She made him laugh. An innocent with spirit, eager to learn. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where she was dark, but otherwise, Rita Cohen reminded him of Marie. The good-natured intelligence that filled the house when she came home from school, full of what she'd learned in class. How she remembered everything. Everything neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 'I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to show you the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it a tough job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often has to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. There's just one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help calm me down,' she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so closed in with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some routine paperwork - organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. A chance meeting with a pop group's manager led to an offer to work behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy. Well, you would too if golf was your passion. There were some downsides, though. A small flat fee is offered, plus a percentage of the winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for the golfer, Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recently recognized by European Tour Productions when they made him a statistical data administrator. From cards brought in by the caddies, he compiles and analyzes the statistics of each day's play. The results are wanted by TV commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to try the food in the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember for the rest of my life than buy a microwave.' His talent as a cook led to the offer of a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director of an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper called to offer him a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his waistline under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I always loved words and enjoyed using them, but my writing was mainly poetry. Then I had this idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a kind of role reversal story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That is what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not up with the dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend another couple of hours typing out the morning's scribbling - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter rather than on one of those awful laptops. I get between 50 and a hundred letters a week, and that is the part about being a writer that I enjoy the most. I do try to answer them all, but nowadays I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust, like golden mountains, reaching down to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed on the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to follow him. Laughing, he watched them from the roof, looking scared, but one by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes until one of the boys said, "Let's go up on the roof again and jump down." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and started jumping off again until only Michael was left. The others were below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, licking his lips with a nervous smile, wondering why it seemed like a longer drop this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and jumping, but it didn't work. He tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. After a while, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we're going to stay here all night?" they shouted, and when he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from nervous sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump, then got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to come home on time for dinner. If you won't come home, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled seriousness, but Michael, with his dark, sad face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the boys laughing at him.

Text: 'Careers Advice Are you unhappy in your job but unsure how to change? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change their job are turning to careers advisers. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a summary of the results and suggestions for different careers, along with any retraining you might need. I decided to try Career Analysts, a large organisation that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. I had to remember it wasn't about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the tests would give an accurate picture of me. They included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I had a long chat with an adviser. Using the test results and our conversation, he wrote a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, though I was a bit upset to learn I did poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I'm sure many sick people are glad I never became a nurse. It was comforting to hear that I made the right choice in journalism. Rethinking your career doesn't have to mean a big change. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for a large insurance company for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she go to Career Analysts for help. 'Losing my job was the perfect chance to step back and look at my career so far. I wanted to re-examine my skills and interests,' says Donna. Some results were surprising. 'I didn't realize I had such a talent for design. But I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial commitments,' she says. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use the skills I already had and move into something more suited to me than insurance. I am now working as a Public Relations officer. I might have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've sent several friends there, and they are all happy with the service.' Some people feel they wouldn't have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make life-changing decisions. 'After working for a major bank for six years, I found my job boring and needed a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. I took the tests, which showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course in it later this year. The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I'm much happier now and more positive.' However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I reached a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many new ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary cut or a lot of retraining. I wasn't told anything about myself that I didn't already know,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same thing, they would have given me similar advice.'

Text: 'Fun at the Dentist's? If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you'll notice bright modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit during their check-ups. Jerome says, 'Half of the people only go to the dentist when they're in pain instead of going for regular check-ups. That's because they're scared.' To change this, he has tried to create a place where people feel comfortable. That's why I decided not to wear a white coat. I think people connect it with pain. My idea is that dental treatment should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and even enjoyable atmosphere.' This is surprising for many of us who think of dental visits as painful or at least formal and clinical. Jerome says, 'If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past bad experiences.' One of his new relaxation methods is virtual-reality headsets. 'We were the first in Britain to use them, and they're very popular. The headsets are used during the first check-up, where the patient sits on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I check their teeth. Then the headset shows a special camera view, giving the patient a tour of their mouth.' Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit. Another important point is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today it smells like orange. Jerome explains, 'When people come in, I want them to feel with all their senses that it's not like a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make people nervous if they're afraid of dentists.' I found the gentle smell in the office very nice. Although he is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, Jerome wants to emphasize that he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it's not painful at all. Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. 'One thing I learned there was that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself,' he explains. He sees his patient-focused approach as the beginning of a slow change towards less formality in the traditional British dentistry field. At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks him what video he'd like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it's no surprise. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a regular dental practice.'

Text: 'Bitter water hits the big time Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a big business worldwide. At Easter, British people spend over £230 million on chocolate. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought at this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate. Large-scale chocolate production began in the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is an evergreen, tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, they become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, a misspelling from the 17th century. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. The Aztecs flavored the drink with spices for ceremonies and to welcome visitors. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar, but the recipe didn't spread to the rest of Europe for another century. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. But in 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans. The chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, combined cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate. At the turn of the century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville (ville is French for town) to add some French style. But then came Cadbury's famous Dairy Milk bar, which started as Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it with the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it a rival to the more luxurious French brands. It seems that, for now, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars each week. This has pushed manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. The latest marketing idea is the 'extended line,' where a chocolate bar becomes an ice cream, a soft drink, or a dessert, to tempt chocolate lovers who are bored with regular snacks. On the production side, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices at the end of the 1980s. Since most cacao farmers work on a very small scale, many had to close their businesses. Perhaps you could think of them as you enjoy your next chocolate bar.'

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83, Peter Cooke has become an expert in his art. He still wants to try new things like paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on making delicate and unique objects from shells. "Tell me if I am boring you," he says as he shows me his work in his apartment. Cooke is not boring; he is enthusiastic, charming, and his creations are beautiful.

He points to shell-covered ornaments above a fireplace. "I won't mind if people don't buy them because I love them," he says. Cooke never planned to sell his work. Five years ago, friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. The result was a show in London where 70% of the pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The pieces are expensive, around £2,000 for the ornaments, but Cooke doesn't mind if his fireplace is empty. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase.

Cooke says he doesn't set the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else makes work like his. The gallery owner told him, "One day you'll stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won't be any more." Cooke wishes he had started earlier so he could have created even more wonderful things. Although he still has ideas, he feels more physically limited now.

His work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. He has a "miniature mind," creating boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and realistic flower baskets. Cooke has developed his own method, using materials he finds. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just does itself," he says, but his attention to detail and color shows it is not accidental.

Cooke searches for beautiful, tiny shells beyond his Norfolk shore, traveling to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people crushing them faster than I can collect them; the sea also breaks them up. I would never collect shells with living creatures or dive for them, but once they are empty, why shouldn't I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty of his work.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, you will probably find her studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

"I'm afraid Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, fine," I said, "no problem." I had been trying to convince myself that all the negative things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided a visit to the hairdresser's was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.

But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. She did not seem selfish; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum, visibly proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was unexpected. Her older sister decided she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should go in for it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When she got the call saying she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to continue, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work.

Kira now finds it hard to manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, a few unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This must be hard for Kira, as she is not self-important. But she says, "They assume that because I've become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she is needed for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get broken, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even take their school-leaving exams. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we find high levels of gold; we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

The father and son have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area around the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing the land and finding bits of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "At the moment, this looks doubtful, although we've got quite a few people we can contact."

As news spread about the dig, the magic of gold attracted the attention of locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau relies on tourists, and residents are cautiously hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would encourage more people to come here if they are right, but if these two find gold, I hope millions of people are not going to come and hack away at the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when thousands worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, the wonder of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. When she is not teaching, she goes on dives to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to dive three kilometers down into the ocean. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can easily touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they cannot stand or move, and must wait for someone to open the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it might not be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It flows out at one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel recalls being scared when she first went down with an American team. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

Text: I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere beneath all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign timetables, currencies, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere in Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, the rhythm rocking you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you have a simple approach to travel and encourages wastefulness, like burning socks that have become too smelly and getting rid of books when finished. This way of thinking is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be thrown out along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to feel this carefree is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be special. On that first trip, my friends and I didn't realize the possibilities of this train ticket, thinking it was just a cheap way to get to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting, as there was always just one more country over the border, always a little further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and in planning our own schedule, we left out everything except the most obvious sights. This was a chance to escape the guided tour, an opportunity to do something different. I was proud that, in many places, all I saw was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and have a good time. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was just a name before. It is as if the city you arrive in never existed until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and seeing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you see it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring. While the train trip won't let you discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to recognize this ... though in our case it didn't happen immediately.

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country to find out that your baggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the clothes you are in for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and have to wear unsuitable clothes. Although airlines rarely say how many bags they lose, it is a fact that regular travelers will eventually be separated from their luggage. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and no airline can guarantee that a passenger's checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially when the trip involves changing planes. 

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to go through the airport and be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between two flights. These times are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Normally, the system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, causing the baggage system to fail. There is also the chance of human error or an accident where the destination label is torn off. These problems can be serious at large transfer airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport handled over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone handled two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, with most moving between Terminal 1 (for Domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient transfer airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage when changing planes is higher at certain airports. Even the United States has issues - Miami airport is known for luggage going missing when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

You should choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes, or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline for the whole trip. Allow more connecting time by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Don't forget to include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

Text: 'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, shading the shallow water. The main colors are soft greens, mud browns, and the different yellows of sunlight, as gentle as the sounds of water in the breeze. The bird moves quickly through the scene, like a flash of light and motion. It disappears in a split second, but its image stays in your mind, its impact much larger than its size. Charlie James loved kingfishers from a young age. He can't quite explain why he is so drawn to this little bird. The kingfisher is part of legend. In Greek myth, it was a moon goddess who turned into a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this. Even though kingfishers look blue, their feathers have no blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light and reflects blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich green, depending on the light. It's no surprise that some wildlife photographers are very enthusiastic about them. The colors, along with the fact that kingfishers can be watched easily from a hideout, make them a lifelong passion for some. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. But it took him four more years to get his first good picture. Meanwhile, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream rich with kingfishers. However, school limited his time with the birds, so he skipped classes and became what he calls an 'academic failure'. But his interest in the kingfisher, the only one of its family to breed in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and gradually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the ultimate kingfisher film. 'No speech, just beautiful images that say it all,' he says. 'I'm drawn to the simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings...' His voice trails off. He's thinking of the bird's colors that still excite him after so many years. His photographs show some of his feelings, but as Charlie knows, there's much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.'

Text: 'Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors'

A. ANNE MANSON
Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected opportunity when she asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up replacing an absent assistant and was later invited to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. No, I wasn't nervous. I've always been comfortable in front of an orchestra." Manson, originally from the US, works with a London-based opera company focused on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has assisted Abbado on several projects since then.

B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE
Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. "If it had happened earlier, I might have disappeared," he reflects. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being known only for the competition: "If in three years my name is still linked to it, I'll be concerned." Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra are inviting him back, which is crucial for his career.

C. WASFI KANI
Wasfi Kani, founder of Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business district until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "Seeing her conduct, I realized size doesn't matter," she says. Kani appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the singers' personalities."

D. ROGER VIGNOLES
"Conducting was a surprise for me, but it's fascinating," says Roger Vignoles, 48. It's not a completely new path, as he started as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he hadn't done before. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like." Vignoles feels his musical experience is valuable and is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys.

E. WAYNE MARSHALL
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, then a young assistant, and recommended him to his agent. Marshall, now 32, soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was challenging. He even had to deal with musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and got the best result I could. Many musicians don't seem to need much guidance from a conductor, but I'm not afraid to express what I want. If you show worry, it gets worse. I've never formally studied conducting, but people have been supportive. I'm determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to try out some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old had a lot of fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay longer. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, especially the trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is great for younger children. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small for it. The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge family**

We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually afraid, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then gets exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't try the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the most noticeable ride, and Ben found it the scariest. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but not all were welcoming. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn't have dared to tell the kids we were leaving early.

Text: 'Running a business in the countryside Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside. A. 'My customers are friends,' says CHRISTINE HOGAN, who runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly income of over £200,000 and four full-time employees. 'My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were young, and I wanted a job I could do from home. I had worked with computers before I got married, so my husband suggested I start a computer-aided design business. It needed a lot of money, and things were tough at first. But I was very careful, always informing the bank manager if I was going to spend too much. Working from home saves money, and I can continue working in the evening if I want. It has stayed a small business. We rarely deliver work - people from the area usually come to pick it up.' B. 'I enjoy being independent,' says MAGGY SASANOW, who works from home as a designer of greeting cards. 'I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where there weren't jobs like that. So I decided to start my own business and I create a range of 50 greeting cards which I sell to museums. I work in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there is always something that needs doing - like mowing the lawn. My business grows completely by word of mouth - I don't advertise at all. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone, I don't get to share ideas with others anymore, but overall there are more advantages than disadvantages.' C. 'It has been hard at times,' says DELIA TURNER, whose curtain-making business has had ups and downs. 'I started my business eight years ago. At that time, this type of business was growing, and in two years my income went from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to manage six full-time curtain-makers. But I had to let them go because of the economic downturn, which was painful because it's not easy to find other jobs in this area. I am almost back to where I started, making the curtains at home myself, with my husband's help, and using women who work from their homes. I have to be ready to lower my prices when necessary and look for different opportunities.' D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. 'I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. The first was financial, because London was so expensive, and the second was because I love the country. I enjoy being able to work when I want to. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at odd hours. The downside is that it requires discipline to close the office door. I publish children's books from cultures around the world, working with authors and artists. All my professional experience was in London, so I used to feel very alone at first.' E. MEG RIVERS runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a yearly income of £250,000 and employs six people, some part-time. 'I started ten years ago at home. I am very interested in health, so I started making fruit cakes, using good quality flour and eggs. Then I started getting requests from friends and relatives, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago I rented a small building and everything is made there - we have a baker and assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don't cook at all now, as I manage the business side. My biggest problem has been the financial side of the business, which has been difficult because we didn't have a lot of money to start with.'

Text: 'Meet the Amazing Watkins Family The sons are composers and prize-winning musicians, while Dad makes the instruments. Matthew Rye reports. Families of musicians are not uncommon, but it's rare to find one that includes both musicians and an instrument maker. When South Wales schoolteachers John and Hetty Watkins needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, they found it too expensive. John says, 'We looked at different dealers, and it was clear it would cost a lot. So I thought, maybe I could make one myself. I found out that the Welsh School of Instrument Making was nearby, and I attended evening classes once a week for about three years.' 'After making a few violins and violas, he tried his first cello,' Paul, now 28, adds. 'It turned out really well. He made me another one later, and I used it until a few months ago.' John has since retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American player Jaime Laredo was a great achievement. Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano: 'As soon as I was big enough to reach the keys, I played,' he remembers. But soon, he was drawn to the cello. 'My parents wanted me to play the violin because Dad played the viola and needed another violin for his group. I tried it for about six weeks but didn't like it. I was more interested in the cello player in Dad's group. He seemed really cool when I was six or seven. He offered to give me lessons, and that's how it all started. Later, they suggested my brother play the violin too, but he wasn't interested.' 'My parents were supportive and relaxed,' Huw says. 'I wouldn't have liked being pushed. Instead of feeling threatened by Paul's success, I saw it as something to aim for.' Now 22, he is making his own name as a pianist and composer. Meanwhile, John Watkins' cello has served his elder son well. With it, Paul won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, a position he held, still playing his father's instrument, until last year. Now, he has a Francesco Rugeri cello, on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 'Dad hasn't said anything about me moving on, but he did try both cellos and admitted my new one is quite nice! The only thing Dad's cello lacks is the power to project to the back of large concert halls, which it might gain after 50-100 years. It will get richer with age, like my Rugeri, which is already 304 years old.' Soon, he will be seen on television playing the Rugeri as the soloist in Elgar's Cello Concerto, part of the new series, Masterworks. 'The performance history doesn't change how I play the piece,' he says. 'I'll always do it my way.' But Paul won't be able to watch himself on TV - the same night he is playing at the Cheltenham Festival. Nor will Huw, whose String Quartet is having its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall the same evening. John and Hetty will have to be diplomatic and energetic to keep up with all their sons' musical activities in the coming weeks.'

Text: 'Looking after the countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden employed by the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense. 'And you definitely need to be good at handling people, because you're always dealing with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building firms.' Gareth was born and raised on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he didn't have formal training. 'I find it helpful that I still farm with my parents and can talk to farmers on the same level and understand their problems. Also, they can't fool me about anything!' he says. His farming life also means he can handle the physical demands of the job - putting up fences, planting trees, building walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth says he has learned more about nature conservation. 'When I was young,' he remembers, 'I used to pick and press flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests. And I thought recently, where would I find all those flowers, the birds' nests, the grasshoppers now? It's become clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault - they were just doing what the government told them.' Gareth says that, when he started his job, farmers and conservationists were against each other. Both sides wanted things done their way. Now they are talking and can see each other's point of view. 'We're at a crossroads and there's just a small step needed to bring them together,' says Gareth. Conservation is one of the main parts of Gareth's work, along with public access to the Trust's land, tree planting and maintenance, and meeting the Trust's tenant farmers. 'My role is to make sure jobs get finished, with as little fuss and as economically as possible. What I enjoy most is seeing projects completed, although about half my time is spent on reports, signing bills, and so on.' Gareth is very enthusiastic about his job and, despite never being off duty, he clearly enjoys every minute of his work, especially talking to the public. Most of them, anyway. 'It's the attitude of some people I dislike,' he admits. 'They just walk into the area, demand everything, then walk out again as if it's their absolute right. Having to be nice to those people gets on my nerves!' But as Gareth says, it's all about common sense really. So if you have plenty of that, and you like the idea of an outdoor job, you might think of applying to become a warden like Gareth - but don't expect a job to be available on the Lleyn Peninsula for many years!'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her typical day includes teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. When asked if people give her strange looks, she said, "I'm too focused on my movements to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra's life is now all about being her best for the Championships. She follows a strict schedule to get fit. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. A home crowd will expect us to start well."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of ability." England is ranked fourth in the world, but the Championships will be tough. "You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance."

In her 15 years at the top level, netball has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. "You train to win," says Kendra. "But after the game, we're all friendlier." Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and must lead by example. I support and encourage my team."

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should parents handle a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know the best way to nurture their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult. While most schools can support children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, especially those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools. These schools are designed to create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, helping them develop their musical skills with guidance from professional musicians. At these schools, students spend one-third to half of their day on musical activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. However, students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, living at the school full-time, which allows them to be with others who share similar goals and interests.

What are the disadvantages? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally gifted children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question the idea of admitting children as young as seven into such a focused environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop 'rounded and well-balanced individuals.'

There is a risk that separating musically gifted children from an early age can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a sense of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer support if needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide about specialist education. Children who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with skilled teachers and opportunities for orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be practical for families living far from major cities like London.

Text: 'An eye for detail Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly and spread seeds everywhere. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening. They left plants that Susan liked and also a gardener named Danny. 'It was really his garden,' she says. 'We got along well. At first, he didn't agree with some of my ideas, but when I explained I wanted to paint them, he understood.' Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. 'I don't set everything up at once,' she says. 'I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one. Sometimes it takes years to finish a painting.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. 'They all bloom together, and you're so busy,' she says. She is also fascinated by how flowers change as they decay. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being in water for a day. 'At first, they seem boring, but they change with twists and turns.' Susan has always loved plants. 'I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers,' she says. 'I didn't like garden flowers then; they looked fake to me. I was amazed by how wildflowers grew in difficult places like rocks or cliffs.' Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and many flowers to paint, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She hired another gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isère, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not 'live in'. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing the guests' breakfast. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last guest has finished breakfast, by about 9.30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go skiing herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4.30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are happy to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4.30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.'

Text: 'Changing Lives with a Stranger'

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there.'

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. 'I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa.'

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, went with the TV gardening show Ground Force. 'I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my job.'

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I would faint, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is a waste of time compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction.'

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and I felt different—people looked up to you. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult.'

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier.'

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journeys**

**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past amazing sea views. No matter the weather or time of year, it is always beautiful. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many rail journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable - we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still on their way. When the train appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages - some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite impressions of trains when they are young, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming took place on an old, disused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my passion for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could, and when I went back last year, it was as if time had stood still. Everything was still in place, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Trying to get published? If you are wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Readers of this magazine often ask, 'I have written this story/book. Can you tell me who to send it to?' The first thing they need to know is that they should research their markets and learn about publishers while improving their writing skills. Turning words into something that sells requires a lot of knowledge about the 'writing game'. Whatever kind of writing you do, you need to understand the markets you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything relevant you can find. Use your local library and visit local bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will guide you on what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any given time. This knowledge must be updated regularly as new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers are always looking for new writers; as writers, we must give them what they want. At first, you may not be sure what you want to write. Let's say you want to write short love stories. The first thing you must do is find out which magazines publish love stories, a limited market these days, and get as many recent copies as you can. Then, learn about the kind of stories they are buying and who the readers are. These readers expect different things from their magazine, and the editor focuses on meeting their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time? Do I stand a chance?' As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. But it is unlikely that the work is ready to be published; so I try to give an honest opinion, but always positively. The problem is that most new writers are too eager to send their work out, usually before they are ready for the market. If you have only written one story or article, it is not likely to be published. That almost never happens. When you read about 'success', you usually find that the person has been in publishing or journalism for years before their current success. When you finally send off some of your work for the first time, start working on more while you wait for a reply; write ten more stories, even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to think of yourself as a writer, and both your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any of them away—improve them instead. Also, I advise not showing your work to anyone else, especially in the early stages. Remember that every successful writer has had many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your career as a writer. See if there's a creative writing course near you. If not, try joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing—every day if possible.'

Text: 'No Title On the last day of a bad year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station didn't feel as airy and clean as usual. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question, then approached a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her. The man asked, 'Are you travelling to Philadelphia?'
