'Well, northbound, yes,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 'Ma'am,' he asked an old lady, 'are you travelling to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I stood up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn't. I probably looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then moved to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She lowered her book. She was around thirty-five, older than me. A school-teacher type. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Why, yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favour?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my wrist, pretending to check the time. (I don't own a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too difficult, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags like pets on leashes. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter's flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; didn't know what to do.' The woman clucked sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where this was going. 'I told her to stay put. Stay in the station, I said, and I would get someone here to bring her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a poor excuse, in my opinion. Also, it was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have made more sense, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel the contents! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Watch yourself, lady, I thought.'

**Gary and Me**

The restaurant owner, John Moore, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef.

I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory and me feeling upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been very good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into our corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He would wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very academic, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he had talent. So when he told me, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for school,' I sent him to a friend who has a restaurant.

Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can achieve. He understood when I told him: 'Gary, if you want to succeed in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it's too late.'

Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping others. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cookery series has become. I'm extremely proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one gives you anything. He's seen the opportunity he was given and took it with both hands. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even ten percent of what you've told them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.

Finding a good flat in Dublin at an affordable price was very difficult, like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way was through personal contacts: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often worked. But if, like Jo, you had just arrived in Dublin, you had no personal contacts, no one to tell you about a vacant bedsit. So, it was a matter of staying in a hostel and searching. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going. Everyone at her school assumed she would leave. Who would stay in a small, remote town? That's all she heard for years. They all wanted to escape, see life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family would help them settle. But none from Jo's year were going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, run by nuns, where she would be safe. Her father hoped they kept it warm, as hostels were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay a whole week in a hostel. But Jo didn't know they were still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. Please, let it be nice, let them like me, let it not be too expensive! There wasn't a queue because it was more 'Third Girl Wanted' than 'Flat to Let'. The 'own television' part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. A red-brick terraced house with a basement. But the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, clearly a failed applicant, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, "Is this all there is? Oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, Jo noted with surprise. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called.' Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said 'Nessa', one said 'Pauline', and the other said 'Other'. 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' she said kindly.

Text: 'Behind the Dolphin's Smile People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in marinas, films, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on their decline. Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the wild seas. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest have made us love them even more. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could become a major wildlife disaster. There are forty different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two usually live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups. We know little about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress. Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to know why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which reduces fish stocks and threatens local fishing industries, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are removed by fishing, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing methods use huge nets that float or are pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show they were caught in these nets. Waste and other substances in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they accumulate in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk rich in pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Perhaps the most controversial threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet understand.'

Text: 'GETTING FIT Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might think this is just another article about fitness, but there are good reasons why exercise is talked about so much. Exercise is very beneficial for you. It improves muscle tone and changes your body shape quickly. It increases muscle strength and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. Good posture prevents muscle imbalances that can cause injuries. Exercise also improves specific areas like thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation. You might have heard these reasons many times and feel bored, but here's something interesting: exercise can help reduce depression and tiredness, and it helps you sleep better. It also controls stress and can help with some medical conditions. By now, you should see that exercise is good for you. If not, just think about it logically. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or weight training. But remember, training too hard or with too much weight can cause injuries, so start slowly and carefully. If you're unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you. Good posture is important for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body doesn't look good, lacks energy, and can have minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling the top of your head up. This helps lift your chest for better breathing and makes your body look slimmer. When your chest is balanced, you can see your ankles when standing. Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and movement, helps maintain good posture, and prevents injuries. Stretching four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit. So, stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.'

Text: 'IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their home comforts for months? The search for the perfect shot. Among all the animals in the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost nonstop rain, causing many unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive tool so that whenever one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. His partnership with the talented producer has created some of TV's best wildlife films, like their amazing and popular film on leopards. Even while this film about one of Africa's shyest cats was being shown, they were already back in the wild, this time following another shy animal, the jackal. But this is common in television partnerships. Traveling filmmakers have been going around the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman about their partnership while he was briefly meeting other people at a safari lodge. 'We do have occasional arguments but we tend to get over them quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and he says they get along well because they both see the animals in a similar way. 'When we are moving, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we have a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each morning, we make the tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask.' The rest of their daily diet is pre-packed meals heated and served by whoever is available. 'It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so food can cause some panic,' says Newman. It can be a tough life, but being alone in such remote areas allows them to get close to the animals and become part of their lives. Newman remembers filming a family of lions where one lioness would regularly go off on her own. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions and even their car. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift', and two years later they went to film Arctic foxes as a team. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they start, they have to submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I developed a good working relationship from the start,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We always aim to create a film that is rich in atmosphere, brings to life the true spirit of the place and animals, and touches people's hearts. I believe if you can evoke an emotional response from people, that is better than appealing only to their minds.'

Text: 'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slawinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.' 'My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. I'm on a strict schedule to get fit for them. These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries taking part. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start well.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they'll be exciting to play. They have lots of ability.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to push yourself to play each day, there's no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance, and you have to be ready.' In the fifteen years she has been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game.' Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'It's essential that we all think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, I think it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team.' 'From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned,' she says. So I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player. She will probably coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.'

Text: 'In Hot Water Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a steel vehicle, about the size of a small car, and dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 'Inside,' she says, 'space is so limited that I can touch the two pilots. We can't stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours gathering rock and water samples, and then three hours to return to the surface.' 'If anything happens and we need to get to the top quickly, we can hit a panic button. The outside drops away, leaving a small escape vessel that goes rapidly to the surface. No-one's tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey.' 'I didn't know how I would react the first time I climbed into the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and I got in with an instructor. He talked me through the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing me to see how I would react in such a small place.' Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year she dived with a Russian crew. 'We went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, their chimneys blowing out black smoke. It is where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effect of a multi-national programme that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.' When she isn't at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. 'Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research into the "black smokers". This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one metre per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.' 'The only time I've been frightened was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-metre rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, "I'm going to die." We stared at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible - we were still alive!' 'It's such an adventure diving to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, there is a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no-one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I had studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.'

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body movement, how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice, and our actual words.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. One of her friends, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher's only comment was, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look as if they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to come across in the best possible way." Yet many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but wasn't even given an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what had happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian discovered that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words agree with your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to appear too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job on the spot. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted to the offer with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss sensed how excited I was, he knew I wasn't going to turn him down. Consequently, he offered me a lower salary than I'd hoped for. I'm sure I could have got more had I managed to control my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests that it's a good idea to learn about the company before you go for an interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and convince others of your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests you have a few questions ready and avoid speaking in long, confused sentences. As she puts it, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was made redundant unexpectedly. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not in an office anymore, but I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. A career counsellor helped me, and I was the first to tell him, 'I don't want to go back to my old job.' Most people in their mid-forties need to work for money, but our children were independent. We moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but our friendships have survived, and many visit us."

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but I haven't. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss social interaction with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's my fault. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control and have peace of mind now."

Text: 'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I've always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped for sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun there with great facilities and nightlife. But I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you can't party late. I don't mind that much, but I love sleeping in, which I often have to skip. It's worth it because without dedication, I wouldn't have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, and if there's prize money, I go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship got me a TV show about surfing. I guess I'm a bit famous now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and celebrate wins in style. Some say we act childishly, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends who aren't in sailing. You can't focus on the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I've only been recognized in public a few times. I wouldn't want to be a celebrity. I get nice letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them. It takes time, but it's worth it. D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping. But it has downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like the attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports; you have to be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me much. I'm happy to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.'

Text: 'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very difficult, says one mother: 'They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't afford all this, and if I give in, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win.' Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a shopping trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and arguments about sugar being bad for teeth don't work well against attractive ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, 'Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food, because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with advertisers and having to disappoint their children.' The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, 'The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, "Ask your mum to buy this," that's still the effect they want.' A big stress for parents shopping with children is deciding which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot about food with her children, but still feels unhappy about handling their shopping requests: 'My son watches ads but is critical of them. We talk about products and look at labels. I've talked so much that he thinks all ads are rubbish. We have less conflict now because the children don't ask for things I won't buy.' Parents also admit they are inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, 'We refuse to buy him sweets because they're bad for him, while we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on my mood. If I'm feeling good, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent.' Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.'

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large 18th-century houses into this hotel. This allowed the hotel to install the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. 

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can adjust the temperature within a small range, and the front desk can make larger adjustments. Business travelers, who make up about 65% of the hotel's guests, will appreciate the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by installing extra cables and renting TVs, so they can be easily updated.

Despite all this technology, the hotel rooms are designed to be comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food must be excellent, and Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel, as he has a modern kitchen and better parking facilities, while the hotel offers a popular dining option without financial risk. With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

Text: 'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I think it's excitement. I need to be doing something challenging. When I'm learning something new, I feel a lot of energy. Anything with rhythm gives me energy, too - right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is wonderful, very expressive, and energizing. I think you can feel tired if you're bored or feel life has no purpose. Being effective in the world - even in a small way - gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all - I love being at work, it's not a chore. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel down even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep, so when I get it, I feel great. When I only get six hours of sleep a night, I feel a bit off. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to find the energy to do it! I do a yoga class once a week before work and try to do a workout at home. But if I've exercised, my mood improves a lot. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon, so it's probably good to eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I don't eat healthily to get my energy - I think it's natural enthusiasm and being positive. I really can't stand people with negative attitudes. I'm quite naive - I think we should all enjoy our lives and seize the moment. Enjoyment comes first. You have to achieve things and set goals. I enjoy what I do, and the last two years have been very exciting. In my job, there are lots of lively young people, and you can't help but be affected by that. I love rushing around for work, having a busy life. I'm very sociable. I enjoy taking photos, but I'm not sure if I'm good at it. I rush to get them developed and can't wait to see them. I've also started writing words for imaginary songs - it's just for fun and helps my mind relax when I'm traveling a lot.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'My energy comes from things I do and enjoy. I believe in what I'm doing, both at work and at home with my family, and I think being positive about life helps. That's why I love working with kids; they give so much and have a natural resilience. Energy is like a natural chemical, triggered by communicating with others - just try smiling at people and feel the thrill when they smile back. It's much better than feeling sorry for yourself. Although I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, I don't have an exercise plan. The most energetic I get is running around with the kids and playing with them.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'What I love doing more than anything is making a garden out of wasteland. I did that once. The garden was solid concrete - I broke up all the concrete and added lots of soil. It was better than any workout or tennis. The other thing that gives me energy is knowing someone wants to read what I'm writing - I find it hard to write without an audience. And I like sneaking into a farmer's land or a wood. If I'm caught, I say "Oh, what a wonderful wood, I didn't know it was private," and so on. I like it because it's childlike.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'I believe you must have an interest in and respect for what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do wears you out. I used to be on various committees and resented the demands they made on my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so direct it into the things that are most important to you.'

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are very important, and speed comes with practice. Your body position affects your balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your body weight; this means leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is crucial in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It's quite simple, isn't it? As you practice, you can gradually make longer movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for skaters. Even professionals fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when falling. This reduces the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn basic figures, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch good or professional skaters, you will see how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, you should regularly do exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include those for the legs, back, and shoulders, focusing on the ankles and knees. After a long or intense session, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder, 15**, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I don't have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gym and school. I try to take training one day at a time. When I'm very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

B. **Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. Some parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was shy and hid behind me, but now she's met people worldwide and gained confidence."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I do it for myself. My goal this year is to join the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

D. **Sarah's mother** says, "Sarah's passion for horses started at age 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

E. **Jane McShane, 10**, is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When playing, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around. I'm not worried about being arrogant; I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like embarrassment."

F. **Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game at 5. My father suggested it. He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to quit, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to discourage her because she's exceptional. If she has this gift, let her reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point because Chris, at fourteen, was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe grows by another centimetre. Every year, more truly tall people are born. Interestingly, this does not mean we are creating a new super race. Instead, we are returning to our ancient size. We are losing the effects of generations of poor diet, with dramatic results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived 40,000 years ago.' For most of history, our ancestors got food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they based their diet on 85 different wild plants. Then about 9,000 years ago, farming was invented, with serious consequences. Most green areas have been taken over by farmers, so just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This poor diet has badly affected human health and size. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought a blessing, was a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, farming spread because it could support ten times more people than hunting and gathering. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished has only recently been addressed, even by wealthy nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. It is a welcome trend, though not without problems. Heights have risen, but the world has not changed much. A standard bed-length has stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have shrunk, while clothes manufacturers constantly revise their products. The question is: where will it end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies keep heat better.) Since the climate warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when well-fed. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even more. In other words, human growth could be offset by global warming.'

Text: 'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV life, but they are still a mystery to many of us. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Among all live entertainment audiences, studio audiences are often seen as the least important. Some people in TV even look down on them, like one cameraman who said they are treated 'like cattle'. I thought studio audiences were just people wanting a moment of fame. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. TV tries to get different people for different shows. Those of us who like watching TV at home can't understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in an uncomfortable studio to watch what you can see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela: 'Why did she come?' It was a chance to be on TV.' Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was 'a friend gave me a ticket'. Few of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit there, crowded with strangers, while someone shows cards with APPLAUD or LAUGH on them - and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager says, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' But is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', while Charlotte liked feeling part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' What I missed was seeing live actors - from my seat, I only saw the back of someone's head. The opening scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio monitor. Going to a studio might be a bad way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most of the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.'

**Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I prefer places where people have left their mark. When I travel, I like visiting charming villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would cycle to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape school. I enjoyed exploring the hilltops, valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt familiar but different. I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a diary, which was my first try at travel writing, a field I later became known for.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by enthusiasts. I always travel first class because it’s not much more expensive. The scenery isn’t spectacular. The train crosses Romney Marsh with its sheep and follows a canal. But I always look forward to when the train goes through back gardens. For a moment, we can see people in their daily lives, making tea or doing chores. I see myself through their eyes, a woman on a tiny train, looking into their homes. I like the ordinary landscape. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer to find something new.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coast. The beaches are hard to reach and rocky, so there are few people. Some brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the sea's beauty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland through valleys full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are few residents and visitors. It’s a hidden, empty, and remote area, and I love the feeling of space. I found it by chance as a student and have visited every year since, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It hasn’t changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It makes me sad that he’s growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon at twelve. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you’d never return. That place was Glenthorne. It’s the house of my dreams. It’s a magical, secluded, romantic place. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

Text: 'HAPPY HUNTING GROUND We are 'animal people' who love being around all kinds of animals. One afternoon, a series of events led to a lot of confusion. My daughter called me at work to say she had found a wonderful pine snake. 'Can we keep him?' she asked. I said 'Yes, but only for one night.' We had a special tank ready for such temporary guests, and one night was enough to admire them and check our natural history book. I was late getting home. I quickly put a pot on to boil when I heard screams from my sons' bedroom: 'Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!' I rushed in. The problem was Domino the cat and Bianca, the white mouse given to me as a Mother's Day gift. (Some mothers get perfume.) Domino, with the mouse's feet sticking out of his mouth, ran around the bedroom, which was full of furniture and children. He was looking for a way to enjoy his catch, avoiding the waving arms. I jumped into the chaos and tripped over something or someone, landing on the floor. As I thought about stopping Domino, I noticed the snake. It was escaping, sliding off the table and onto the floor. I crouched as the snake moved with its strong body. The room was a mess of cat, mouse, kids, and a barking dog. The pot boiled over in the kitchen, so I turned off the gas and returned to the chaos. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and pulled the small, wet, but unharmed mouse from his mouth. Interestingly, the same mouse was caught by the same cat three more times but eventually died of old age. Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I looked at the snake for a weak spot. It didn't have any. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth without a flute. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, but its eyes were still watchful. I carefully slid my hands under the snake and stood up, walking to the end of the garden. I pointed it towards a tree, hoping it would live happily there. When I let go of its head, expecting it to attack, it instead slid over my shoulders like a shawl, getting comfortable. We stood there in the evening light, four children, me, and the snake. My eldest, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific comment: 'You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't.' I had the children gently encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it did. Without looking back, the snake climbed the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, three-year-old Clay summed it up for all of us: 'Boy, that was one big snake!'

Text: 'Drop me a line! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. Yet, for me, receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by any other form of communication. There is the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from, and the enjoyment of reading it. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I would write to my mother. My mother always insisted I write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or untidy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Sometimes my father would write, and it was always a joy to receive his long, funny letters. Most of the letters from home were about everyday events concerning my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but it is the letters I remember most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I seemed to attract people who had to work or study away, and I could only stay in touch by writing. But instead of harming the relationships, letter writing seemed to improve them. I found that I could often express myself more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but how much better to have a year's supply of news! And it's even better when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters arrive from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked her for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would be poorer for it. As it is, we now have a regular correspondence. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success, however, came this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was amazed that a correspondence could last so long. The local press even considered the correspondence worth reporting on the front page. I am pleased that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother before me, I insist they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends of their own in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly urge readers not to let letter writing become another 'lost art'. '

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art in the Alps**

In the French Alps, at Mont Bego, there are tens of thousands of ancient rock carvings. These carvings, which are about 4,000 years old, include images of cows with horns, fields, and gods and goddesses. Scientists are worried that these 36,000 drawings are being damaged quickly and might not last for future generations. The site, once a place for prayer, is now popular with tourists. Unfortunately, some visitors are damaging the carvings with graffiti. 

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says that people mistakenly believe the drawings will last forever. He has seen tourists walking on the carvings, which wears them down. Some even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. When visitors can't take clear photos, they rub the drawings to make them more visible, which causes further damage. Others scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.

Experts disagree on how to protect the site. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, suggests closing the mountain to the public, except for guided tours. He believes this is the only way to save the site and allow research to continue. However, Jean Clottes thinks this is too extreme and would upset local people. He believes they should do everything possible to preserve the site, as it is a historic monument.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He thinks the best solution is to allow people to visit but admits it's hard to stop them from causing damage. He suggests charging an entrance fee to pay for more guards, as there is no government funding available.

Annie Echassoux, a researcher, is worried that easier access to the mountain will lead to more damage. She believes the area should be roped off and guided tours provided. She insists that money must be found to protect the site, as it is a historic area. If no action is taken, future generations might lose these important drawings.

Text: 'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very difficult, says one mother: 'They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't afford all this, and if I give in, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win.' Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes during a shopping trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and arguments about health don't seem strong compared to the attractive ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, 'Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about this because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with advertisers and having to disappoint their children.' The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, 'The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, "Ask your mum to buy this," that's still what they want to happen.' A big stress for parents shopping with children is deciding which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads, and now they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says, 'We say no to sweets because they're unhealthy, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy treats, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on my mood. If I'm feeling good, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent.' Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.'

**Going up the wall**

In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, you can have a challenging climb anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd is silent. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more famous for the TV show Gladiators, but both the show and the climbing championships have one thing in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new and fast-developing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing angles. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. With cliffs unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This kept their fingers strong and helped them avoid boredom.

Soon, many sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges. These early walls were inspired by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He set natural rock in concrete blocks for walls. Many such walls were built in sports halls during the 1970s, but they had design problems. They could only be vertical, unlike natural cliffs with overhangs and angled rocks. Once built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored with the same holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a material shaped like natural cliff features. These could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers wanted something new. French manufacturers also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere. This system of changeable holds gave climbers endless new challenges.

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. Acting is indeed a risky career because there are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, while others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But choosing to be an actor is a personal decision, and only you can be responsible for achieving your dream. There are no easy paths - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after training, you will succeed in the profession. It's all about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new faces and talent, and acting can be exciting, glamorous, and sometimes rewarding. People often ask what talent is. I think it's natural skill plus imagination, with imagination being the hardest to judge. It also involves courage and belief in what you're doing. Why do people want to act? It's hard to explain why you want to act. In theatre, the important thing is the moment of connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is central to all acting and motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeeded, they might just shrug. They know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they don't take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is an actor's biggest enemy. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs. Suddenly, you get an audition, but even if you want the job, you might not get it. So, actors don't talk much about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of competing for roles and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, from the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. It's up to you because if you don't care enough, no one else will.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of top cookbook titles now available.

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes. Recently updated, it remains the go-to cookbook for many.

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, *Blanc Mange*, accompanies his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by explaining how and why ingredients work together. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 recipes and explains why some dishes might fail, using basic food chemistry. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows his skill.

C. *Le Cordon Bleu* is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. For 100 years, this famous cooking school has trained students to achieve perfection. To celebrate its anniversary, the school released the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, featuring 100 respected recipes. While the recipes are classics, they are still fresh and have been updated to be healthier. The book starts with kitchen basics and includes sections on Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from around the world share their famous recipes and secrets.

D. Fast food? Not necessarily bad! Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, challenges the idea that good food requires long cooking times. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This book includes over 200 recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Written in his fun style, Nigel proves that fast food can also be great food. Try his recipes—they're simply delicious.

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point because Chris, at fourteen, was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe grows by another centimeter. More and more tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we are creating a new super race. Instead, we are returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We are now overcoming the effects of generations of poor diet, with dramatic results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found that they based their diet on 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, which had serious consequences. Most of the planet's green areas have been taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has negatively affected human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing of the New World, was actually a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times the number of people who had previously lived off it as hunter-gatherers. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, though not without problems. Heights have increased, but the world has not changed much. A standard bed-length has remained at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, while clothes manufacturers are constantly having to update their products. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some programmed upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we are likely to reach it sometime this century. However, scientists add one note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller because of better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies are best at keeping in heat.) Since the climate warmed, we appear to have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when properly fed. And as the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even further. In other words, the growth of human beings could be offset by global warming.'

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was made redundant unexpectedly. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. Supplying them helped my reputation grow, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not in an office anymore, but I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. A career counsellor helped me, and I was the first to tell him, 'I don't want to go back to my old job.' Most people in their mid-forties need to work for money, but our children were independent. We moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but our friendships have survived, and many visit us."

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner, so I left. Some people thought I'd get bored, but I haven't. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss socializing with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the product."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control and have peace of mind now."

**Onto a Winner**

Two brothers are turning their childhood game into a successful business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties with bushy beards, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, the family played the game every weekend and holiday, and as Dave says, they were 'having the best time ever'. When the family moved to New Mexico, they continued to play with Grandpa's pichenotte board, made from old wooden food crates. Visitors were often curious because the game was unknown in southern USA.

Three years ago, Dave noticed the old board was cracked and worn, so he decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted another. To see how much interest there was, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people said, "No way I'm playing that silly game." But once they tried it, they couldn't stop playing!

When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched and found that it likely started in India with a game called 'carroms'. It was adapted into 'squails' in Britain and brought to Canada by British immigrants. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. The game, played by two to four people, requires skill. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' to flick across a board using one finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole earns 20 points, and there are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight small posts act as obstacles. The game usually lasts two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the bar, the Lagasses made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. The game became so popular that championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, so the brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board, made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg and is 1cm thick. Norm says, 'They're very durable, as they have to stand up to lots of wear.' The boards are sold for $595 each on their website.

There are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, but the brothers hope their garage will soon house a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they believe will bring them success.

Text: 'WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE When you first enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a piece of unused land, flat and covered with wild plants. For a long time, people thought it was worthless. But with careful planning and hard work, one man, with the help of his wife, turned this land into the beautiful place you see today. Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the landscape you see now. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was also needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted, chosen carefully to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far as Canada and New Zealand. The whole village was designed by Colin Sims, and he made over 100 models over nine years since the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastics to survive all weather conditions. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself. You will notice that all models are made to the same scale, with great attention to detail. This was achieved through patience and unique building techniques. The Model Village is a popular attraction, known for its high-quality work and upkeep. The techniques used here have been applied in other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses. All the model buildings show traditional British architecture and are not based on any specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone structure with a brick tower, common in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition. Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models; a small mistake can cause hours of repair work. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome on a short lead. To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press them to see the models in action. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. New models are always being planned, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if any models need improvement. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us.'

Text: 'Every week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy and break the newspaper editors' rules. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, people in the public eye are hurt when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization made to handle these issues. These pictures are rarely in the public interest. Do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where she should expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. It's shocking that the PCC didn't investigate on its own. It should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star didn't make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other unfair attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. These would be reported by other newspapers and on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it would no longer be profitable to wait for celebrities to take secret photos. If the PCC decided to act like a 'police officer', which it could, there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't.
