Above all, the task is too big. How could the PCC realistically watch all of the British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there is the embarrassment to consider. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the extra embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story they have kept from the press, and they know it might come out if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. One British comedian also suffered when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', saying it was just a joke, and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.'

Text: 'There is a lot of advice for college graduates starting their first job. In this article, we will talk about moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for a second temporary job while searching for a permanent one. Nor are we talking about those leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. Instead, we will focus on those of you taking a real step in your career, choosing a job that matches your goals now that you have some experience, skills, and an idea of where you want to go. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to ask yourself if you want to specialise in a certain field, move up to higher responsibility, or change to a broader field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is the time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then get your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again. Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a perfect first job because 'OK ... they were very supportive. I learned about office work and improved my word processing skills. However, there was no chance to advance. One day I quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.' Juliette now works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years I have become more capable and my job has really grown,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to develop me. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. From mainly typing and phone work, I now do most of the correspondence and budgets. I also handle various questions, from chairmen of large companies to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves me in all her work and gives me specific projects and events to organise.'

Text: 'Confident people: what's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were born that way, but most say it's a skill they learned. Nina Hathway asks five people how they did it. A Jenny When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be like that. At twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous, but I did well, and someone suggested I take a university course. I was scared on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school was a turning point in my life. B Michaela Four years ago, my father got ill, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I thought confident people were like that, but I learned that confidence means believing in yourself. If work is too much, I don't feel guilty about leaving tasks for the next day. When faced with something hard, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lack confidence, so I talk to myself to overcome it. C Lisa People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. I learned to look confident because it's important in TV. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous, and we feel better when talking to someone friendly. My mother once said, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves.' I remember this. You gain confidence by facing fears. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed and felt less scared after that. D Barbara My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I've built it over time. By learning from mistakes, you're more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let it bother me. You have to like yourself, not be what others expect. My company offers training courses that boost my self-esteem. They also encourage setting achievable goals. It's better to achieve small things than aim too high and get nothing. E Kim After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak in meetings. I eventually gained the confidence to share my opinions. In politics, I was nervous speaking in public, but I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' Writing notes helped me feel secure. Everyone feels nervous speaking publicly. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.''

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled as I gave him his torn kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, finders are keepers ... and I have many more.' He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them in the shade of the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held up the kites, and a row of competitors holding their kite lines waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had registered for the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each had entered four different designs to be judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying efficiency. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how it's done.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large room. As it got dark, he asked me to come again the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains with lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my eye. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' Before starting, it would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tented kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects under my thin mattress. The night was completely dark, full of sounds. A waterfall roared nearby and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a great view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, wind, then lightning hit the treetops. Seconds later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the huge raindrops. I also worried about my car being swept away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. No one is a stranger for long here. Back in Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, everyone asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were very friendly. Kelantan might be best known for its kites, but I remember it more for its human kindness.'

Text: 'What kind of shopper are you? Whether you love it or hate it, we all go shopping. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which one you are? Abby Edwards asked around ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I'm an addict - I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple! B. Brenda, 40, office manager I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband how much I've spent - I always say it cost less! The real price always sounds shocking. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do, I know what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and there's always something I'd rather be doing. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes at the back of my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes gets it wrong! E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy, everything is messy, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish quickly! F. Lisa, 22, actress I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out to look around the shops with my friends, and we often end up spending. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I'm a careful shopper - I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go crazy. I sometimes shop to cheer myself up, but I usually feel worse because I've spent too much! H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on a Saturday because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a fair idea of what I want, and I never buy things immediately. I have to look in other shops in case I find a better bargain - I take ages! I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager I'm an unwilling shopper - maybe because I work in the city center, the shops have lost their attraction for me. When I have to, I'll drag myself out, but I don't bother to try things on, it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much, and I'd rather make a few mistakes than go into shops and make a lot of effort!'

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE Like other universities, the Open University offers degrees. However, you can continue working while you study. It can also introduce you to many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the new experience of learning more. You will meet different kinds of people. Your qualification might also lead to new job opportunities. You don't attend lectures at the Open University; instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can attend one class a month at an Open University center if you want. There are exams to take, just like at any university. If you want more information, simply fill out the form below. It could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and asked questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**

The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch 18th-century artist Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) of flowers and fruit is in light, bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons. Miss Violet Churchman donated it in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. It is now in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus. Also featured are Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until 31 May.

**Lecture News**

A series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists "tell a story" through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery is happy to announce that the restaurant now has improved and expanded services. With new kitchens, it offers a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**

Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest pictures and show the range of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble preparing onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends which they really enjoyed. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. Fees must be paid at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organisation that provides outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. Groups should inform the centre before visiting.

Windsurfing - One-day course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. Course fee: £32.50 (includes all equipment).

One-day adventure course
This is a great opportunity to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. The course introduces outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You don't need to be very fit or have previous experience. Just be interested. Course fee: £22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country, with sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses
We offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. We have three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer adventure holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that children only do activities suitable for their age and abilities. Children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health for this programme.

Text: 'STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW Millions of people of all ages enjoy a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collection and find an interest that can last a lifetime. Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. Holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from family, and letters from pen pals can all give you stamps from around the world. Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these in three ways. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope addressed to you, or send the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts. Or, if you prefer, we can send you the individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book. The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you could become a member too, with a two-year membership costing just £5. You can even get a discount if a group of you join at the same time. We think you'll agree that this is great value for money. When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get our helpful 4-page guide to collecting, which has more ideas on how to add to your collection and includes useful addresses of shops and businesses that sell stamps. Every two months, you'll receive a copy of the club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes, and gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world. Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unusual ones that are out there waiting to be found. So join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. To join the Club, simply complete the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent within 28 days of receiving your application.'

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the euro are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to make. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green the farmer would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges, including Mary Littlejohn, the novelist, Michael Brown, the TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, Keep Writing's editor, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here is some advice to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who wrote for us did this. Love, family, and problems with friends were the main topics. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about ordinary things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right Don't describe a town or explain how something works if you are not sure about it. Avoid writing about things unless you are certain. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A poor ending is the worst. Develop the story carefully and try to think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story come alive for the reader by using well-chosen words to make them seem real. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you might miss the closing date, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, your story cannot be returned, nor can we discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country - a change in the rules by popular request - and the story must not have appeared in print or in recorded form, like on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. Your fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month of this date. Please note that if you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured his daughter received the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have copies of her books, but we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to help with her work. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone connected with it was in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometres long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough in the east and ends at Wansford, which is next to the A1 main road. There is a 2-kilometre extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line.

**Fares:** 
- Adult: £10.00
- Child: £5.00
- Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00
- Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It is a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from Europe. This includes the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', which were built in Britain. These engines are on display all year, even when the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. The James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Booking one month in advance is required. Special low fares are available for groups of 60 or more pupils. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programmes can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, etc. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Text: 'Grass Grass is probably the most successful plant in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they are found everywhere on Earth. They are the only flowering plants that can live in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands support many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All of them depend on grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This is why large groups of animals can live in one area. After they eat all the grass, new grass grows quickly, providing fresh food.'

Text: 'The Young Achiever of the Year Kal Kaur Rai has always loved fashion and has just won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she has drawn clothes and designed patterns. She never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make her hobby a career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked in an advertising agency. She had to go to industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making skirts and tops for herself. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them. She found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes were very popular, and nothing was returned. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear label. Kal's parents were not upset about her career change and said they would support her, which made her very happy. Her clothes are now sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over £500,000. Her designs appear in fashion magazines, she creates clothes for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Her business has grown a lot, and she knows she is very lucky. 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.''

Text: 'SUNNINGDALE HOTEL The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has offered excellent service to people from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed at Sunningdale. The hotel is on a main road leading to the town center. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the center, and buses to many parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with the blue sign Express on the front because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away. The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking available in the hotel drive. Daily newspapers are free, and stamps can be bought at the office. Guests staying for long periods must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast 7 am - 9.30 am; lunch 1 pm - 2 pm; dinner 5.30 pm - 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner. No animals or fires (for heating food or rooms) are allowed, and guests should respect others' comfort. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests are advised to use taxis to reach the hotel if they arrive by train, as it is some distance from the main railway station.'

Text: 'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life wasn't always easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved being in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his thousands of fans worldwide.'

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking questions. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, the cat's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

Text: 'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia, from the warm northern coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my journey. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train - there are few stops and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, although the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally built to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship, would save time and money. A transcontinental railway is rare, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners, eager to board. Our first stop, where the Ghan waited four hours, was at Katherine. Some passengers got off here and took a boat trip up the gorge. I didn't leave the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now and few people do. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs isn't very interesting. There is a lot of flat land, with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over and, although the train might not have delivered on everything the advertisements promise, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.'

Title: Climbing to the Top of Britain

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, and my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred meters high and is probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard it feels like ice. Even though some of us were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothing. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon went up, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we were not so lucky because a mist came down. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as climbing up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we have just moved into our new school building! It is an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. However, this new school is one of the first in my country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, so we watched it happen. It was exciting to see the builders clear the space for it, although it meant losing some nice open land. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are much bigger than those in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people in the town for meetings and other events. There is also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and large changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside, and it keeps the sound in too. If we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that there is a tree on the school roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that it can be seen from miles away! We took some pictures to put on the website.

Even though we are already using the school building, some parts still need to be added. For example, we are putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**

Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

As a special offer, you can choose any reduced-price books from our new members' book list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money on the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully chosen from our book list by our staff. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**

As a member, you'll save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month, keeping you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. On the Internet, you can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**

All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff select a Club Choice book—a work of fiction or a reference title they think is worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just indicate this in the space provided on the form. We will send the book if we do not receive your response.

So, return your application form today, but hurry—offers like this don't come every day. To apply, simply fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you your bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You should then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn't know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained what had happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what had happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the telephone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to drive over to return it. I got my handbag back, amazingly with all its contents untouched. I would like to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day, and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the most frightening animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. Sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if sharks are turned over on their backs, they can stop moving completely. This is helpful for researchers who need to study sharks. It allows them to learn more about these interesting animals.'

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only £1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Scheduled flights with Australia's national airline, Qantas, from London or Manchester to Perth, returning from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, Air Australia flights between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. Coach from Sydney to Melbourne via Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia. Nineteen nights' accommodation in quality hotels with full continental breakfast. Day trip to Ayers Rock, a full day Barrier Reef boat trip, a visit to an Australian sheep station, and city sightseeing tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes. Hotel baggage handling. Experienced Globewise Tour Manager throughout the trip. PERTH Beautiful long, golden beaches, excellent restaurants with great food, lush green parks, and the lovely Swan River. City sightseeing tour included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to famous Alice Springs in the heart of Aboriginal country. Full sightseeing tour. See the Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Drive to Yulara National Park. Visit the mysterious Olgas and Ayers Rock with its caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Fly on to the lively seaside town of Cairns and relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF We've included a full day's boat trip on the famous reef with the chance to see amazing, brightly colored fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY You'll love the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city - we've included a sightseeing tour and a visit to the famous Opera House. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE We've included a city sightseeing tour - or you can visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip you'll want to return!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around and asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they started talking in English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once to talk to her because I felt a little lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are very hard, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. That makes me confident I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the DVD finishes. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I like walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when I couldn't believe how cold it was. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. At the moment, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

Text: 'THE ICEHOTEL For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people thought the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an art show in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of foreign guests decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide. When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As each part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the finishing date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks. It is a good idea to wear shoes that are larger than normal to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture shop, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's regular hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening. A police officer who was called to the shop said: 'The police knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The shop was soon full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could enter, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space for them inside. Another problem was the long line of cars trying to get to the car park. What surprised me was that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the shop. This blocked the road completely.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. So I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

Text: 'Membership The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. Started in 1899, it is now one of Britain's most active arts groups. Society Magazines We produce several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by top British writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing scene. You can see articles from recent issues by following the links on this website. National Short Story Competition We run the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and short stories on any topic are accepted. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members pay a fee of £5). The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best entries will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will receive a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories. Education For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and building confidence in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, open to writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and are invited to a five-day course taught by professional writers. The Writers' Cafe The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. Relaxed and stylish, with freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks, it is the perfect place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also offers monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11.00 am to 10.00 pm Monday to Friday and 11.00 am to 8.00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events. Becoming a Member We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.'

Text: 'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on just one breath. In 2003, Tanya Streeter made history by diving 120 metres deep and returning to the surface without help. She had gone deeper the year before but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, becoming the only woman to break a man's world record in any sport. A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive at different depths. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of several serious accidents, but Tanya disagrees. She believes safety and training are most important. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine stays the same. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land at the gym, and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, choosing fast walking instead. When she starts practice dives, she usually travels away from home. She aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, resting every other day to avoid getting tired, which could ruin her preparation. When not preparing for an event, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes by doing research or making films. Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, she loved swimming and exploring rock pools to watch sea life. Tanya says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. She believes people listen to her about environmental issues because she is well-known in some countries. Looking to the future, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to keep breaking her own world records. Since she started free-diving at twenty-five, she doesn't plan to retire from the sport anytime soon.'

Text: 'CARTOON FILMS Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, some directors had new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was successful. The Black Cauldron, for example, did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.'

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role 'I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. She was surprised at first but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6.00 am to write the essays I missed. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I definitely want to make acting my career. I'm not from an acting family, though my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything because I had a full social life too. When filming finished, I hardly knew what to do. I've since appeared in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends.''

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my only goal was to earn enough money to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is an international company growing quickly around the world. Over the years, I have learned a lot. Much of what I have learned is in this book because I believe our company has something important to say about running a successful business without losing our values. This is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel like part of a family, and be excited by new experiences. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with the world and makes them public. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that an exciting thought. I hope you do, too.'

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can host 160 guests in double cabins, each with an outside view, private shower, and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning and features a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May for the night.

**Day 2:** Enjoy a morning tour of Oporto, then return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This river journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** Continue up the river, stopping in the early evening at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. Dinner will include local food and drinks.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum. The museum, once a palace, has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return to Tua is by coach, with many sights along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take the Douro Valley railway to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

**Day 7:** Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, travel down the river to Oporto and sleep on board.

**Day 8:** Arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before flying back to London Heathrow.

Text: 'HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey is usually milder in taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who used it as payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. However, honey is not just food - it can be used for sore throats and is in many skin and hair-care products.'

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of the largest towns in England. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself independently.

Today, Norwich is quite small compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as weeks in the year and as many pubs as days in the year. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and success as a commercial center, Norwich offers a wide range of entertainment: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the city center as builders worked on the project. Nearly a million tons of earth were moved to create a city center park on the roof of the Mall, with water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are successful, showing that Norwich has combined the best of the old and the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, about twelve hot-air balloons took off from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at the current site outside the city.

**What to See**

The balloon pilots stay in radio contact and light up their burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. To see these 'glows', you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can even take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a view of the festival from above. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are essential. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you use film, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

Text: 'The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist attractions. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many products we use every day come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold the weather is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a large waterfall. Another zone copies the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to build a desert zone soon.'

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality, for £6.99, quite amazing? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less well-known writers seem to focus mainly on food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it just after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes! There is excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are also pieces from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Finally, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and an extraordinary piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is an exceptional collection, and I can't wait to see what next year's choice will include.'

Text: "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to start teaching pupils at three and four years old, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's pupils have group lessons. Each group has about twelve pupils, and each lesson lasts an hour, once every two weeks. In addition, each pupil has one individual lesson a week with her. Parents also have to attend the classes. It is important that the parents show interest in the lessons. From the earliest lessons, pupils learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and reading of music. Margaret says that her method is not meant to produce great violinists, and she always suggests that pupils who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Text: 'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' follows their previous CD, 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined as the new drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later tracks are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but they could easily become hit singles because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems. This issue has caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who has bought tickets should not worry as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create great music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

Text: 'San Francisco San Francisco is on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He first saw it in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was found by land instead of by sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The richest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.'

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time, like disease, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, even about his faults - he often slept during church or looked at the pretty girls. He describes his home life - a quarrel with his wife and how they became friends again, and his worry about her illness. Besides books, he liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and plenty of fun. Pepys was a busy man who had many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work for the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not made to be comfortable or fashionable. Early shoes were probably made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles in cold weather. We still use leather today, but other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional skills, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to make many cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I wanted to help more women try running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to give them the confidence to start. I decided to create a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with many race organisers. They complain about the lack of women in the sport but use it as an excuse not to provide separate changing rooms. I put up posters, and 40 women, both young and old, fit and unfit, joined. They were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had really considered running before. When they thought about it, they imagined difficult training. They didn't think about chatting and smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they ran for only a minute - now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about diet and staying fit in general. I wanted to support women's running, and I've enjoyed watching their progress - almost as much as they have.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built. One of these towns was called Iditarod, meaning 'far, distant place'. In 1909, it grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During summer, supplies could be delivered by boat, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making travel impossible. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothes to gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to cross Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' for a warm bed and food for both the drivers and their dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams. However, in 1925, a disease called diphtheria hit Nome. The medicine needed was in Anchorage, far away. Airplanes were new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in the cold. Also, the only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams six days to complete. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide him through the snow. The last part was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to go further, saving the team from icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the 1925 route. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.'

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so putting hot drinks on it is not a good idea! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothes are also available. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in the summer and is rebuilt each winter. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Text: 'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football in an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' The story appeared in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who had supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her playing football outside the club. He immediately noticed she was fast. 'He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs really hurt.' But Jose visited her parents and convinced them she could be successful, which would help end their poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had refused before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She explains, 'They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.'

Text: 'The Skywalk The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You must wear special shoe covers to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the air.'

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest and are only a few hundred miles from the center in the more southern regions. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as amazing. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You start from Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. This city is located between the water and the mountains, allowing its residents to ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey is still a great adventure. You sleep on the train, which is fun, but you travel through some of the best scenery at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago, when the rulers of China opened a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many early zoos, animals were trained to perform for visitors. This does not happen anymore, and now zoos are places where people can see animals behaving naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. People who support zoos say they give us a chance to learn about the natural world and be close to wild animals, which would not be possible without zoos. On the other hand, some people are against zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals live in dirty conditions and eat unsuitable food.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played on stage! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to play in it gets accepted—only about half do. But anyone who is eager to play goes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country—I’ve been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. But I find it exciting because it's both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music, but you also feel you're part of its history, as you're playing on stage like great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who have supported us all the way. Without them, we wouldn't get anywhere with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime between November and March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Recently, many winters have been dry, so when it rains, local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens exist not because of the rain, but because of underground channels dug in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year. Dry places that get water this way are called oases. Further south from Marrakesh is Skoura. Here, small squares of land are made by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow in winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis, 13, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try to find full-time jobs with a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus during the summer and return home for the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."
