"People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Text: 'Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8-18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to national and local newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites to be published. The news stories and articles by our members that are accepted can be read or listened to on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers where young people can meet other members and join projects, and we plan to open more centers across the country. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities they had. Age wasn't important; they were trusted to do the stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll be trained and take part in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff who go with them on these trips. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free and there is no test to join.'

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, Antarctica Sightseeing Flights takes tourists in a large passenger plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to another date if we need to change the flight day.

**Questions**

These are answers to the most common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.

**How long is the flight?**

The flight usually lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we start seeing the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have lived on research stations in Antarctica give talks about the environment and history, and answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you a pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, passengers switch to the seat on their second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane to share the sightseeing opportunities. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting points so everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different approved flight plans. Our captain checks the satellite cloud pictures on the morning of the flight and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them in detail. We do not land on Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. To see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes! All cameras are welcome. We even offer some fun onboard photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble preparing onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends which they really enjoyed. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Winter Driving

Winter driving is dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can hide under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. A car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. 

Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, when you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it.

Rule Number Two is to pay attention to what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. 

Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.

Craigie Aitchison

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law, but instead, he went to art school. There, he found traditional drawing classes difficult, but he continued painting. In his late twenties, he received money from the Italian government to study art. He became interested in early Italian artists, which is visible in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian fields and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. This led him to paint colors thinly, layering them from light to dark, but he says he's never sure what the results will be. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.'

Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he never makes drawings before starting a painting, as he feels that if he did, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are finished. This is why his favorite models are people who don't ask to see their pictures while he's painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.'

Since moving to London, he has not felt part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but just paints the way he can. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we didn't like the idea because of the noise. Ben said, 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'Okay,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are hard to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must say that, although their music sounds a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill - after all, I didn't expect my parents' generation to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their school work because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Text: 'Atlantic College Last week I visited Atlantic College, a great private school in Wales. It offers young people important experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to study for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They study in the morning and do useful activities in the afternoon, like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking for pollution in rivers. One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different social backgrounds and countries. Since not many can pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, grants are available. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get government help. "I really admire the college for trying to encourage international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn't believe how much less I argued with my sister." In conclusion, Atlantic College provides its students with an excellent education using methods that really seem to work.'

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a good salary, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me. I felt stuck and became unhappy. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy and hopeful, and I wanted to be part of that. Now that I'm a student, I find it hard to connect with younger classmates. They often think I'm a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. Still, I am grateful for the chance to study because I know a qualification is important for getting a good job, which matters a lot to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. There are also benefits like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I sometimes worry about what I'll do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age is a good decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic, and in 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make affordable cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he created the first Ford Model T, which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer choices. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs £150. If you prefer to start in June, we have another 10-week course for £200. I hope this is the information you need. Yours, David May '

Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before she climbed the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is difficult. 'You must carry everything on your back,' she said, 'so you can only take what you need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I am usually a clean person, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!' When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now she has written a book about the trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science programme on television. Rebecca is well known today and has more money, but she still lives in the little flat in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!'

Text: 'Dear Mike, I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a great party; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some nice presents. I'll tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo'

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places. The winters in Canada are so cold that the birds would die if they stayed. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn.' Bill had a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn's cold weather came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back. They didn't arrive, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, but Esther used her aunt's money to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon doubled her aunt's £500. At first, her parents didn't want Esther to spend her time making jam; they thought she should study instead. They hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor one day. But Esther didn't listen to them and continued making jam. After a few months, she started selling it at the local market. Then she began making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked. After two years, her business grew very large, and her parents were very pleased with her. She made all kinds of food, which she sold to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she had to hire some people to work for her.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to come to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I'm very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you invite Karen to go? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline '

Corryvale Farm Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each one produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to keep them cool. Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters with the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. But it was summer, and the weather was hot, so people didn't want to buy sweaters. She then made some socks. Everyone loved them because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. That's how Jenny's business began. At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers, so she had to send the wool to a factory, where all the socks are now made by machines. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. On the walls of Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers all over the world.

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made many new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like our teacher a lot. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also said that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave a door or window open. Night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home then. Winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark, and they can't be seen easily. Many houses are empty at that time because people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to keep burglars away. He also asked neighbors to watch other houses in the street when people are not at home and to call the police if they see anything strange. 'We will also tell you how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of help costs nothing.''

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, I'm writing to thank you for the two nights I stayed at your lovely home. It was nice to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you asked for. They're good photos, aren't they? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera. I am going to visit my sister in New York next week. I will take many photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time. Thanks again. Love, Roy'

Text: 'The History of Farming Before people started farming, they went to the forest to find plants or fruit they could eat. This meant that people were always moving to find food. But about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and their villages slowly grew bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers grew food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was hard when the weather was bad, and then some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it travels thousands of kilometres from where it is grown to our homes.'

Text: 'WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years after that, she got her current job as a manager. This is what she said about her job: 'My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach air hostesses and help them with any problems. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer and then talk with some of the air hostesses. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I like office work too. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I can do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling.''

Text: 'Dear Maria, It's nice to be back home in my country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I would like to return to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even harder. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8.30 a.m. train to Cambridge on 10th May. It is a large blue bag and my name is written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms Johnson, I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6.30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson '

Text: 'People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for different jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers spent a lot of time looking at the sky, animals, and flowers to understand the weather. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if there is a red sky in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. But for the past few months, they've spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who had trouble with reading. Kevin learns words more easily by seeing pictures and hearing information than by reading. His brother wanted to help. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make a computer game, and now it's ready to use. It's a speaking and picture game. For example, if you look at the word 'hat', there's a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their computer game, and it will soon be on sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in buying it.'

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I go home to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But it's hard to sleep at night after a concert because my head is full of music. Sport is important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports centre for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. I can't do that now, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well. I drink a lot of water because it's good for your health. I should have about eight glasses a day, but I don't always drink that much. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but there are other things I like doing too. In my free time, I just listen to music or watch TV. It's good for you to do nothing sometimes. I don't get tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now I eat lots of things like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

Text: 'Bollywood'

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces almost 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, making it the largest film industry in the world. Most Indians prefer watching films over any other leisure activity, and ten million of them go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films often tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of every film. Indian films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make, while a Hollywood film is never made for less than $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan, who some people say is India's greatest actor, is different. He has starred in more than 140 films during an acting career of almost 40 years.

Text: 'Bill Bryson I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived there with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have lived in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the United States. I think they will be happier because they have lived in two countries. I like Britain and want to return, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so it won't be for another four years. I recently went to England for six weeks to work on a radio program about the English language and to talk about the book I just wrote. Most writers don't like doing this; they don't like traveling around the country to promote their book. I don't mind it. I enjoy visiting new places and meeting many people. It's very different from my life in the United States when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.'

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer arrived more recently. The name Giant is fitting because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, which needs to be cut often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep, and the police use them because they are very intelligent. A Schnauzer is a nice family dog. It is friendly and very good with young children.'

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two big towns. 'It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops where we could buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.'

Text: 'Dear Keira, Thank you for your letter. I had my first day at my new school today. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms were. She is very nice, and I will visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I must go now because I have to do my homework. Hester'

Text: 'New books this month The Long Night This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for several years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia, where she works in a small hospital. One day a baby is very sick, so Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They face many problems on the way and ... Hard Work This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long, hard hours making tables and chairs, but they do not have much money. Then one day a man dressed all in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop ... Hospital or Cinema? Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star ... What will Tina do?'

Text: 'The history of horse racing Horse racing has always been an important sport. It started in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago and was popular in Greek and Roman times. Modern horse racing began when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. At first, races were long and only between two horses. But at the start of the 18th century, races became shorter and had more horses competing. Today, horse racing is watched by more people than any other sport in the USA, except baseball. It is also very popular in other parts of the world.'

Text: Nick Barlow is a world traveler who loves his job. He is a British actor and travels around the world to make TV programs. "People welcome me everywhere I go, and when I get home, I remember all the wonderful things that happened in each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still a few trips he wants to make. "I'd love to visit South America and go back to Australia one day," he says. On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring the cameras and other equipment needed for filming. Nick doesn't take many personal items, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always makes sure to pack some books. Nick's wife, Helen, doesn't mind his traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he returns, she enjoys listening to his travel stories. But sometimes there are problems. When he was in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick heard that his wife was ill in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so happy when I heard she was better."

Parrots

You might have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in large groups, and because they like to eat fruit, they can sometimes be a problem for farmers. There are many different types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet, which they use for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds, and it is easy to teach them to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometres west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much more difficult to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he has done the right thing.'

Text: 'John Pickering In a park in a small town in central England, John Pickering takes care of the grass and flowers. But last week, he was in Tokyo, and millions of Japanese people watched the thirty-five-year-old gardener on TV because John is currently the top singer in Japan. John went to Japan a few months ago to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on his radio show. Hundreds of young people called the radio station and asked to hear the songs again. John, who uses the name Jon Otis when he sings in Japan, is not planning to quit his job in the park in England. He does not know yet how much money he will make from his music. 'I must keep my job in the park,' he says. 'I still have to pay my bills!' The other gardeners do not know that he is famous in Japan. They have never even heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, 'This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!''

Text: 'Memo To: All staff Subject: Holidays From: D Brown Date: 22.2.02 I am organizing the holidays for next year. Please let me know when you would like to take your holiday. If possible, could you give me two options? Please reply by the end of the month. Thank you. D Brown Memo To: D Brown Subject: Holidays From: J Green Date: 23.2.02 Could I take two weeks' holiday in July? I prefer the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Also, can I take three extra days in the first week of December? John'

Text: 'Line dancing Thousands of people in Britain have a new hobby -- line dancing. In almost every town, you can find clubs and classes for this activity. 'Line dancing is easy to learn. If you have two feet and can walk, then you can do it!' says Fiona Lever, a teacher. 'You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are both young and old people. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!' When did line dancing begin? Most people think it started about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.'

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have big, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's large body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are usually quiet and calm animals, and they only eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live to be 50 years old.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, there are policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London had no policemen at all. A few old men used to guard the city streets at night, and they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was starting to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people stayed in their homes as much as possible. In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to stop thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had become very big and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was started with 3000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are quite well paid, and for the few police officers who still ride horses, the pay is even better than for the others.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Would you like to join a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest in the school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. It gets very cold at night, so you should bring warm clothes and wear strong shoes. If you want to come, please let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks every August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are lively with music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even see artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these performances are quite cheap, and it is usually easier to see your favourite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so why not book your hotel now!'

Text: 'ICE-FISHING If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake turns to ice, and thousands of Canadian fishermen go there each weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice. Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. 'You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy,' he says. 'First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport and you can meet some nice people here!''

Text: 'From: Greg To: Anna Hi Anna, I'm not having a good week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us! Then my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't come to stay with us during the holidays because he has a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school! She didn't tell me she needed it. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Write back today if you can. Greg '

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's A very famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. At this museum, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor who made wax figures of people and opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was sent to prison. There, she had to make copies of the heads of famous people after they died, including Queen Marie Antoinette's. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802 she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.'

Text: 'BICYCLES The bicycle is an affordable and eco-friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were expensive, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we have today. Later, as bicycles became cheaper, many people bought them. People began riding bicycles to work and during their free time. Today, people use cars more than bicycles because cars are much faster and you stay dry when it rains. However, some people still prefer to cycle to work. They say there are too many cars in city centers and it's hard to find parking!'

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their keepers and stood in front of large white cards. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started to paint on its card. Sometimes, the keepers gave them a new brush with paint and took the old one away. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants drew pictures. I couldn't believe it! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest ones live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Text: 'Big Cats There are many different types of big cats. They vary in size and do not look or behave the same. Tigers are the largest big cats. From head to tail, they can be 3.7 meters long. Most cats don't like water, but tigers often lie in water when it is hot. Lions are the only big cats that live in large family groups. Several lions may work together to hunt for food for the group. They usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily follow other animals. All big cats need good eyesight because they catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I am sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month. I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sorry to leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me.

Thanks again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write back and tell me when you are free and where I can meet you. Hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I'm happy because last month I got a new job in the city center. I am working in a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to get up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I like telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me. I'm wearing my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are only a few left. Ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when running. Ostriches can run very fast, between 65 and 90 kilometers an hour, so it is hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and take about 3 years to become adults. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without water.'

Text: 'Snowboarding Victoria Jamieson from Britain began snowboarding at the age of 20. She is now 23 and has won many competitions in this sport. We talked to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she started snowboarding. 'I've always liked sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It doesn't take long to learn, and you can become really good in a few months.' We asked if she practices a lot. 'In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. But I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains. It's so beautiful. But free-riding, which is doing what you want when not in a competition, is the best thing for me.' We asked what is important when learning. 'You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet because, at first, you spend a lot of time falling down!''

Text: '23 Oak Avenue Manchester Dear Sir or Madam, I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights from September 15th to 17th. I prefer a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could I have a quiet room on the ground floor, please? I will be driving to the hotel. Does the hotel have a car park? I expect to arrive at around 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive. Thank you for your assistance. Yours faithfully, Mark Jones'

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is considered the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers make it to the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and the temperature can be below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out of their homes at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move in the water at more than 10 kilometres an hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very polluted, so many fish and insects died, and the otters couldn't find food. But today, there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.'

Text: 'Dear Deshini, I'm happy to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family. I'll send more next time I write. I hope you'll write to me soon. Tom'

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a very good teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then return home to Greece. I like London a lot. We went to Regents Park by bus yesterday. It was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I'll write again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I am going to visit your country next month with two friends. We don't know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We would like to stay in the centre. Can you help us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the centre are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always made buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to keep beautiful things safe. Many people work together to create a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, the workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. But the building is attractive from every side, not just from the top. There is also a famous roof on the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This interesting building looks like a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a picture of a very large man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. Nobody really knows when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

Text: 'Gail Rollins Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 meters - and maybe the 5,000 meters - at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in big races. But she always laughed and smiled, and people in her city love her for this. Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, a very long road race. She won with the fastest time of the year for any British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he injured his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. But it's not fun for Mike when Gail runs past him and he can't catch up. Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. But she always rests from running on Sundays. 'I am with her all the time,' says Mike. 'Sometimes I say, "Are you sure you should be eating that?" It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost everything.' '

Text: 'Young Piano Players Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. At ten, he decided to write music and soon composed his first song. Oleg Gagarin Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him traditional Russian music. At six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano skills. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years, then returned to Russia. Josef Heptmann Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now but hopes to write his own music one day.'

Text: 'Bill Prince-Smith Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me when she doesn't like something,' says Bill. 'My ten grandchildren don't live nearby, but they also read my stories and say if they are good or bad.' This way, Bill has learned what young children like to read. Bill writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His fifth book is his favorite: The Sheepdog is about a farmer and his helpful dog. 'I have always liked animals,' says Bill, 'and dogs are so clever, they learn very quickly.' Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film.''

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because they are cheap, and the pictures are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century. It showed a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards had pictures of news events from that week, like an accident or an important person's visit. People liked these because newspapers did not have pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they died out about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. We don't know exactly why they disappeared. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs looked different from each other. There were more than 5000 types. Some were very small, while others were huge. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was stronger. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because of its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they cannot see well and, like most animals, they find food using their noses. There are seven kinds of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two kinds of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. But not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Not many pandas live in the forest today because it is hard for them to find food.'

Text: 'CROCODILES Crocodiles live in warm parts of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat anything they catch, like fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are more than ten types of crocodiles. All of them have very sharp teeth. They often lose these teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. Crocodiles can live for a long time. The oldest one in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.'

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon that could carry people into the air. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first plane with an engine and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Aeroplanes changed a lot over the next thirty years. In the 1950s, planes became much faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour, making the journey from London to New York only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by aeroplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to watch plays by William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors ate, talked to friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Text: 'Dear Jeff, I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is very warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different here: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home! See you at the end of September. Sue'
